text: Good. So, hi, hello everyone. Welcome to  the launch of patentpandas.org, and I am so   excited to be here. Thanks to the Media Lab  for allowing me to host this awesome event   and also kind of helping me through the crazy  disasters that I'm about to share with you all,   to make this resource possible. First of all, I  also want to thank the Berkman Klein Center where
I'm an affiliate right now for also connecting  me to so many resources again that have made   this possible. Many thanks to come later on  in this presentation, so let's get started.

One more thanks to Carol Lin is who my kind  of co-author and co-pilot in the PatentPandas   project. Unfortunately, she's unable to join  us tonight, and so I just want to give her   a giant shout out because so much of this work  would not have been possible without Carol. She   is from the Cyberlaw Clinic at Harvard Law  School and that's where she's a student.

To get started, patents are kind of  far away for many of us including me,   less so now. To give you an idea of what it  feels like I found this lovely video clip   that I'm going to use for educational purposes  only. Let's see if we can get this to play. Oh,   no. Oh wait, is there sound? Oh, no, there's no  sound. I'll just describe what's happening.

There's a girl, and she's just doing this funny  dance. The stork is like, "What do I not see? Oh,   my gosh. Why is she so weird?" Glass. We are  in a glass factory. That's why she's walking   and running so weird, and then she's like, "Oh,  my God, storks can't see glass." Then of course   there's the wolves coming. This bird is me, and  that's what it felt like so much of the time that   glass is patent law. It's invisible to me, but  very, very important. That girl is like all the   lovely lawyers that I've been working with who do  see the glass and who can help me navigate these   invisible force fields that will smash my face. That's what it's like to deal with patent law and   hopefully I can share a little  bit so that you do not have to   smash into the glass as badly as I did. Two stories. The first story is about LED   stickers. This is what an LED sticker is. It's  an LED light that's in the form of a sticker.
It started out as a research project back when  I was a student, a Master's student here at the

Media Lab where my collaborators Natalie Freed  and Adam Setapen created a class project where   we handmade stickers that are circuit elements  like sensors and outputs including LED lights,   and we made them in this fun, interactive  scrapbook. That was back in 2011.

Then in 2013, I met my collaborator Bunnie Huang.  We went to Shenzhen to explore manufacturing and   see how we could use work with factories to  scale research projects and deploy them out   into the world. My project for that was the  circuit stickers, and this time instead of   using a team of grad students, we were able to  collaborate with factories and use manufacturing   processes to product these stickers. Here's an LED sticker at scale. We were really   excited that it actually worked, and so here is  our first set of stickers. There are some LED,   sensors, and even a programmable microcontroller.  Normally these projects would live in the lab,   but we decided to see if we could get them out  into the world by doing a crowdfunding campaign.
So we launched a crowdfunding campaign for circuit  stickers on Crowd Supply in November 2013.

We were very, very delighted that our funding was  successful, and six months later in June of 2014   we were able to ship on time, and this is largely  due to Bunnie's extreme skill in getting things   made very quickly and then shipped out. So that  was great. Then we weer able to get our stickers,   our circuits, our papercraft, all over the  world and now educators like these folks can   start learning circuity using arts and crafts,  which was our intention with circuit stickers.

All was wonderful until fast forward to February  2016 we get this email from an acquaintance that   says, "Hey, guys, there's this crazy extremely  broad patent that seems to cover your stickers,   and it seems to be a ripoff of your work. Here's  what it is." We checked out the patent. What was   it? It was these things. These are called  Liteseeds. They are also stickers that are

LEDs. They were created it turns out by  one of our crowdfunding campaign backers,   which we know because all of our backers  are available on the crowdfunding website,   which you can see right now. This is the person that created those.

Not only that this person named Jill also created  her own crowdfunding campaign in 2015. To give you   a comparison of what this is, here's our crowdfund  video from 2013. You see you lay down copper tape,   so we're using craft materials to build  circuits. You stick down the sticker,   add a battery, it turns on, and it glows. That's  basically the idea behind circuit stickers.
Now you can see this other one. Here's  her video. Oh, there's no sound. Well,

I'll just let it play anyway. Basically, she  comes in. She describes how she did this work   all on her own. You can go to Kickstarter and  see the video yourself. Here she's using a pen   to draw a circuit, and then she's going to add  a sticker. We'll just go back. You get the idea,   so rather than confusing you guys with videos. How did this happen? What do you do when someone   tries to patent your stuff. That's the important  part, right? Well, first off, don't panic. That's   the worst thing you can do. yOu want to send  like an angry email to somebody, right? Actually,   that's probably not going to help. It's one of  those things where like you have the right to   remain silent, anything you say can and probably  will be used against you. It's a little scary,   but it felt a little bit like that situation. Next, with all that angry energy, you should   make a list of prior arts. So all the projects  that you've done, that other people have done,   that are related to this work that happened  before to prove that, indeed, the stuff happened   before somebody tried to patent it. So this is  what my prior art list looked like. Finally,   you can then look up the patent on the  USPTO website. It's called Public PAIR,   so we did that. We found the patent, and we  found that she had filed her provisional,   this is like the earliest, earliest in August  of 2014. This is months after we had shipped   our product, many months after we had done  the campaign that this person had backed.
With this information you're ready to find  legal counsel. Find an actual lawyer, an expert,   someone who can actually help you. That's super  important because that glass is very invisible.
You definitely need your lawyers to help you. What  we ended up doing is we tried to submit a letter.

It had already passed examination, which means  the patent was already accepted by the USPTO,   but we thought maybe emailing the lawyer could  help. We emailed a lawyer, showed them some of   our prior art, and unfortunately nothing happened.  The patent got granted in March of 2016.

So despite our company, my research papers, all  the news articles, the patent still passed, and it   turns out it's because examiners have very little  time to review a patent. They have 12 hours to   read it, understand it, search for prior art, and  then write everything up, which is not a whole lot   of time. As a result, things will be missed. In fact, it turns out they pretty much look right   now mostly for other patents for prior art,  which it makes sense because there's so much   stuff out there, let's start with patents  which are at least written in a legal way   that's easy to cite. Of course, thankfully  there are now other projects that help,   so a quick plug is the prior art archive that  was just started here at MIT with Cisco where   it allows people to submit nonpatent prior art  and then the patent examiner will also look at   that. As that project is growing, hopefully that  will provide another avenue for examiners to   find prior art that's not patents. Why? Because  patents are really hard to get and expensive.
Timelines are important when it comes  to law, and just to review we've got

2011 we started the project, 2013 we did  our crowdfunding campaign, we shipped   the sticker. In 2014 June a couple of months  later our backer files a provisional patent,   so this is like the simplest thing possible. Two  years later almost February 2016 we find out that   that application even exists, and a few weeks  later patent issues. That was a sad story.
But it's not over because guess what? About a year  ago I get this email from Jill herself saying,
"Hey, want to buy my LED stickers' patent because  it's relevant to you?" At this point, we're like,

"What?" This actually is about a year ago,  and the patent is still active. This whole   situation is still active, but actually we're  okay. Why are we okay? Because we haven't gone   after her. She hasn't come after us. We have  so much prior art to defend ourselves with.
We just kept making LED stickers as if the  patent was not there. So far our company,
Chibitronics still continues to be able to do  this and get our work out into the world.

That's kind of the important part for me, that  we can continue to create, to innovate, and   get our things out into the world and do what's  important and not kind of get tangled up in these   legal fights. Even though it's kind of shaky,  to me that's a win. That's the first story.

The second story is electronic popup books.  Something else that I love is blending books   with electronics. This is an electronic popup  book project that I did back in 2010. It was my   first project here as a grad student at the Media  Lab. It involved making sensors out of paper and   adding lights and interactive elements to popup  books that are also like programmed, make sound,   glow, move. I also worked on adding electronics  to sketchbooks, so how you sketch in circuity and   explore telling stories using electronics. Here's  a story about the LED who dreams to be a star, and   this is kind of the book prototype that became. In March of 2014, I was invited to go to a place   called Google ATAP. It's kind of an  exploratory small group within Google,   and they were interested in new storytelling  interfaces, and they were particularly interested   in books and electronics as a way to tell  stories. I went in there as a visit. At first,

I thought it was just visit the space, and frankly  I got to meet my heroes. It was mind blowing what   they were doing there. It quickly turned into a  job interview where I was meeting with people who   were like, "Oh, you should work with us." In my  mind I was imaging, "Oh, maybe I'll get to do a   summer internship. This would be so cool." By the end of the day I was meeting with the   director of the entire department, and she  was offering me a job. She wanted me to   start immediately because my work was relevant  and so there was that. It was kind of amazing,   right? However, I kind of came back. I would've  had to take a break from my PhD. I was just in   my first year, and so I asked many people for  advice, and the answer basically was "Stay in   school. Don't leave just to do this project  at Google." I decided to stay in school and   pursue my PhD, which I'm very happy about. Two years later I get an email from a friend   who is a paper engineer. She does popup books  professionally saying, "Hey, look, check this   out." Turns out Google is applying for patents on  popup books with electronics in them. It happened   to be picked up by a popup book blog because  they're like, "Whoa, if Google is doing this,   it's going to be so cool." Unfortunately, it  looked a little bit familiar because a couple   of the inventors on this patent application are  actually the same people who I spoke to during   my visit. When I visited them, I visited them in  March, and their provisional was made in August   of 2014, which is months after we'd spoken. They  did not cite any of my work in their patents.

Just to give you a recap on the timeline. In  2009, I made the popup book, March 2014 I went   for what turned out to be the job interview,  August 2014 they filed the provisional patent   on the popup book. Note August 2014 is also  when the LED sticker patents were filed,   and then in March 2016 it was basically about a  few weeks after I found out about the first one,
I found out about the second one, at which point  I was like, "Wow." So a brief interlude.
Head blanket, because head desk hurts. That's  kind of how it felt. It wasn't even bad anymore.

It was just kind of absurd and funny that  this was all happening at the same time   independently of each other. So here it is. Again, don't panic. When someone else is trying   to patent your stuff, don't panic. Make a  list of prior art, look up the application,   and find legal counsel. Luckily, I had  done all of this about three weeks ago,   so I was much more calm the second time around.  Here was my prior art list that I sent out to   the lab. The cool thing about prior art is as  long as it's made and has a verifiable date, it   doesn't have to be a big publication, it doesn't  have to be yours, it works as prior art.

In fact, a cool trick is if you have a  website that you want to turn into prior art,   submit it to the Wayback Machine, which is the  Internet archive, and that will automatically   stamp it and make it permanent. That's like a  cool trick that people use to make prior art.
So just know that. If the application hasn't  been accepted, if it's not a patent yet,   you can still submit prior art directly to the  application, so that's a thing you can do.
We looked it up, and we found what it was. We  found that it was submitted after I had visited,   months after. Luckily, this is where the magical  moment comes in. So the director of the Media Lab,

Joey, happened to know the director of ATAP  directly, Regina, so we were able to contact her   directly and make a connection and try to sort out  this kind of hairy situation. She was basically   like, "Oh, there must be some misunderstanding."  We ended up getting in a call with their team,   and I remember during this call they actually  offered if they added me as an inventor to the   patent, then would I be okay? At the time  I was like, "No because I'm not the only   person who works on popup books and technology.  There's so many people. You have to add all of   them too." I basically turned it down. What I didn't realize at the time is that   there's a difference between an inventor and  an assignee for a patent. The inventor is the   person who comes up with the invention. They're  like the designer. The assignee is who gets the   rights to actually use the patent. So one way to  think about it is an architect designs a house,   but whoever owns the house actually lives in  the house, and that's often not the architect.

It's kind of the same situation here. What would've happened is if I accepted,   maybe I would still be an inventor but I would  not actually be able to use my work legally   because the rights might be owned by Google.  Right? I accidentally dodged that one for a   totally different reason, but now I know. That's  something to know about. What ended up happening   is in the middle Regina actually left the company,  but she thankfully put us in direct contact with   the senior counsel of ATAP. They took all that  prior art, all that anger energy that took to   make because it's like when this is happening what  else do you do? You make a list of prior art.
They took it and they submitted it to the patent  application, and then the application ended up   being rejected. Now it's abandoned, which means  it's in the system but it's actually not a patent.
In fact, it's kind of cool because now it's  prior art that's not a patent, which is the   strongest prior art you can have if it's already  in the system, which is kind of a good story.

Something to note that I've also learned  is that big companies actually often have   bonuses for patents. So what does this mean?  A lot of large companies have their own legal   teams. They give people financial bonuses  just for even disclosing work. If you get   your idea turned into a patent application,  that's another bonus. If your patent issues,   that's another bonus, so there's a lot of  financial incentive to apply for patents.

Maybe it's possible that they actually  didn't care so much about the work but   wanted bonuses. Who knows. It's a very  different thing. I mean, if grad students   got bonuses for applying for patents, I  suspect there would be a lot more patents   coming out of universities. It is what it is. What I learned is that even though I just want   to make things and kind of ignore the legal side  of making, it doesn't ignore me, and it doesn't   ignore you. So what is this? It's patent law. What  we did is to create patentpandas.org. This is a   website that shares all of these learnings, all  of this kind of mess that we've all kind of gone   through and turns it into something hopefully  friendly that everyone can benefit from.

With that a quick kind of introductions.  Here's PatentPandas. That will do. Also,   before I proceed too much longer, let's go to  about ... I want to ... Oh, that's not what I   meant. Hello? Is that ... Sorry. While I mess with  my pointer. There. All right. Okay. Awesome.

This is a website that was created  collaboratively. All these cute panda   drawings are drawn by my sister May, so grateful  for her creative contributions. It was cowritten   with Carol Lin who again unfortunately couldn't  be here, and Ira Winder, my partner, was the   one who actually built up this beautiful website  where everything lives and lives stably in a way   that's easy to access. This is PatentPandas. Everything that we write on here has also been   reviewed by law clinics, so we've had support  from the Harvard Cyberlaw Clinic, the Suffolk
Law School Law Clinic, the University Southern  California IP Law Clinic. We've had support from

Andy Sellars here who runs the MIT BU Law Clinic.  So many law clinics. And I say this because it's   important to note that there's resources out there  to help you. You're not alone when something bad   happens. One of the things that we made sure  to have on here is ... Where's my mouse? Here,   which is it's a list of pro bono resources.  So these are free law clinics from schools   or from volunteer lawyers groups across the  US, and we're actually now contacting law   firms who have their own individual pro bono  programs, which means that they will do this   for free to help you if you qualify. If people are in trouble, they can find   help. That was very important. We're very,  very, very grateful that all of these folks   and more everyday continue to say, "Yes, please  list us. We want to help." That was awesome.

Then we also have stories. So I want to share what  it's like to work with lawyers, to have something   scary happen to you. I get the sense that in the  world of NDAs. People don't really talk about this   a lot, but I think it actually happens more than  we think or more than we know anyway. So I wanted   to share my experiences, and hopefully there will  be other people who would like to share their   experiences so you kind of know the human side  of what it's like to kind of go through this and   maybe learn from other people's experiences. There's also resources. This is the part where

PatentPandas comes in. All of those stories  will point to specific resources, and these, for   example, are about different topics and inside,  here's one, is What is a Patent? They're explained   through these little comics. So, for example,  one of the things that I wanted to share is all   that stuff that I couldn't find online. If I went  online searching for resources, which I did, most   stuff that I found was either trying to scare me  or sell me something and usually they were trying   to do both. I wanted to create something that was  not trying to scare or sell anything to anyone,   just to give good information so that people  can make their own choices about patent law.

That's why we're telling all of this. All  of the information is being reviewed by   legal experts so that we know it's good and  worth putting up. Then everything is taught   through these amazing panda comics so that  they're a little bit easier to take in.

And then all the information is stuff that  is kind of counterintuitive because patent   law is so counterintuitive. You have a  patent, and maybe you probably know that   a patent is kind of the right to prevent  others from using a particular invention,   using, selling, importing, making technically.  But what you might not know is that just having   a patent doesn't mean you can actually use it. For example, giant panda comes up with a cool idea   to put a rake and an umbrella together to make an  umbrella rake. Giant panda gets a patent on it.

Right? Giant panda is very happy. Unfortunately,  red panda has a patent on a rake, and so since a   rake is part of the umbrella rake, if you don't  have access to all of the patents that make up   something, you can't actually do it. Here's giant  panda kind of sad. However, if red panda is like,

"Oh, I want to make umbrella rakes too," but then  giant panda has the patent on umbrella rakes,   so red panda also cannot just make. It leaves a situation which can be kind   of sad because neither party can do what they  want. Unfortunately, this happens a lot. What   it is trying to encourage, I think, is for  inventors to work together to cross licenses   to share their inventive rights and maybe  benefit everyone by sharing, so you can do   things like cross licensing and patent pools. I will note that a lot of this is still kind of   an exclusive thing because, guess what? To even  get a patent in the first place to cross license   is really expensive easily costing ... A cheap  patent is $10,000 probably. Will probably cost   more and takes about two or more years to  get, so they're not easy things. You kind   of have to have resources to begin with to  participate. That's an interesting one.

I'll show you one more, an umbrella rake. I can  go on forever. Another post that I thought really   interesting was open versus closed. So when I  hear patents I'm like, "No, it means you can't do   something because it's patented." Actually, what  a patent does is it gives you the right to decide.
You can think of it as someone who owns a piece  of land. Someone might say, "Get off my lawn.

Don't come play." That's how patents are typically  used. They're like, "You can't come here. Don't   use my invention. Don't come onto my lawn." However, you can also be a patent owner that   decides to let everyone use your invention. You  kind of don't prevent anyone. This is like an   open patent, so like you turn your land into  a public park. Anybody can come hang out. And   then there's the option of not patenting at  all. That's kind of like this wild land with   no one claiming the rights over it. That's kind  of the most open option of all. Of course, then   there's the issue of other people coming along  and claiming it. That's kind of hairy. There's   a little tiny panda in the distance with a flag  ready. In reality, as a spectrum someone can say,
"No, you're not allowed to use." They can charge  a fee called a royalty, or they can allow people   to use it for educational purposes if they  make it clear. Or they could just be like,
"Yep, all my patents are open." There  are ways to open license patents too.

I thought that was interesting because initially  it was like, oh, patents are bad or all like stop,   right? No, actually it just gives you the  right. Again, because they're so kind of   expensive and challenging to get, they're not the  most accessible things in the world. There's lots   of other stuff like that that I won't get  into. You get the idea. That's kind of our   resources. Then you can learn. You can read  stories and commiserate with others. You can   get help for yourself. That's the idea. I hope  that there are folks who if they're interested,   we're looking for people who want to  contribute resources or contribute   stories. That would be super amazing. I guess with that I would like to give tons of   thanks if I can find my mouse. Here we go. Play.  Did that work? Yeah. I was going to say this was   not a project that I did by myself. It took a huge  village. I've already noted some people. Joey who   has left, but he also kind of was supportive  through the entire experience. Kate Darling   as well. There's my legal experience, right. When  we were going through all this, I talked to Andy,

I talked to Joey, Kate, my collaborator Bunnie had  a lot of experience. He was kind of suffering as   well in the case of Chibitronics. We had so much  help. Andrew Torrence, another law professor who   connected us to these awesome law clinics all  over the US until we ended up working with the
Stanford Law Clinic on our case. It was really,  really amazing how people were excited to help.
I just want to thank all of them. There's so  many other people even in PatentPandas. Let me   think. There's Carol Lin and Jess Field from the  Cyberlaw Clinic at Harvard. There's Ben Virgin and
Loletta Darden from the Suffolk Law School.  From the USC Law Clinic, Caitlin Devereaux,

Austin Stanley, and Jeff Pearlman. They actually  helped review all these posts to make sure it   was good, so I'm utterly indebted to them. Again, Andy, because he gave us advice on what   to write about. Of course I would like to thank  Joe P, my advisor, who was there when I was a PhD   student suffering through all this and helped  kind of talk me from the edge as well as Mitch

Resnick who provided me the space afterwards,  and my mentor Sally Rosenthal who also had a lot   of experience and just kind of dealt with the  panicky version of me, which is not very fun,   but I'm so grateful. These are all lovely,  lovely people who helped me get to here.
With that, I'd like to invite Joe up to share  a few words. So Joe's been around at the Media

Lab. Joe P is professor of the Media Lab of the  Responsive Environments Group, and he's kind of   seen a lot of these situations perhaps come and go  and has a lot of experience within IP law as well,   so I was hoping he could share with us just some  thoughts about how this connects with research   and the experience as students and as an academic  doing innovative work. Then we can break out to   questions. Thank you. I guess we'll share this. Thanks Jie. I'll have a seat. I've got nothing   formally prepared, but Jie and I talk a lot.  We've hung out since and during and talked   about patents. My experience with patents has  been in many different areas. I've got a bunch   having been MIT faculty and researcher for many  years, so we file. When we do most of what I do I   file them very little. We file maybe one or two  patents a year. When we do it, we tend to see   something as a potential product. If it looks like  it's enabling research, it has a lot more left   before it really anneals, I don't really know what  I would patent. We just let it go. We publish.

We publish it on everything. But if it feels like  this could be a product and one of our sponsor   companies in the Media Lab for instance could  run with or a student could do a startup around,   then we'll file the patent. I've been through  that process. I was head of the IP division here   or the IP group at the Media Lab for a while,  so I kind of dealt with everybody's patents   and lots of these stories for a while. The last  five or six years I was spending a small amount   of my time like many of us MIT professors with  gray hair that have done a lot of work in areas   that have become big in commercial like in my  case wearable sensing we get asked to be expert   witnesses all the time I patent cases. In the last few years I've said yes to some   of them, gotten involved, and really have seen  on the other end in intimate detail how patent   cases are actually prosecuted and what people  do about patents. As a matter of fact, what I   generally do is I basically take patents out. I  blow them away. I know about the prior art. I've   been working actively in the field. Eighty percent  of the patents that go through IP review, this is   the streamlined patent review that doesn't involve  district court, which is a cheaper process. Still   we're talking potentially 100K on hundreds of K,  so it's a corporate level thing. Eighty percent of   them get blown away because they're bad  patents for exactly the reasons you say.

It's not always a malicious inventor. As a matter  of fact, what you're talking about here are cases   of fraud. This is outright fraud. It's not just  somebody innocently stumbling into an idea,   the idea is already there, they don't know,  they file a patent. The examiner doesn't know,   the patent gets granted. There's an excuse there  because somebody is just out in the woods and not   doing their homework, and they file a patent. These people knew, and they ripped you off. So,   that goes deeper than just innocently  stumbling into your woods. I mean,   this is to some extent fraud. This is a deeper  set of issues. I'm not a lawyer, but that goes   deeper. Yeah, there are a lot of patents where  basically they didn't know what was around,   inventor writes a claim, could be somebody  working at company who writes a bunch of claims,   but if you're working in wearable computing  especially with the stuff that I was doing   back in those days, we all kind of did this. You can't just say that this patent is bullshit,   pardon my language here, this is PatentPanda  after all. This is bull ... You have the   emoji. Bull emoji. Because we all know look  at this paper. No, you have to make a detailed   argument. You have to go claim by claim. You  have to talk about exactly how the prior art   relates to the claim in particular, and you have  to do it with the right nomenclature. So this is   what lawyers do. They're very good at it. I still  can't really write like that completely, although

I work on these documents all the time. It's a careful process. Every claim that's   there if it's dangerous you have to shoot it down  with this argument. I mean, you see patents use   companies use patents. There's a reason for it.  You know, I'm not anti-patent. I think patents   can be used in terrible ways. I am anti-gun  in many ways, but there's that argument guns   don't shoot people, blah, blah, blah. I don't buy  that one. In patents though it's one of the ways   the companies interlock. It's one of the ways  they relate to each other. They each have this   whole suit of armor of patents. When they come  interclash around an idea and application domain   where they're building product, the patents  are the ways that they basically decide to   work. One of the ways they do that, right? You have that great idea where they share the   cross license. That oftentimes happens. Sometimes  it happens painlessly. Oftentimes it starts with a   scrimmage where you hold your patents out, they'll  hold their patents out. They'll hire someone like   me to blow away their patents. They'll hire some  other professor to blow away our patents. So it's   a whole battle. It escalates. There's district  court case, it gets huge. Companies can afford a   bit of this. If it gets out of hand, they'll  usually settle. How big the companies are,   how big the stakes are, that will define when  they actually cave and when they settle.

It can get to be tens and hundreds of  millions of dollars. It can be just   some thousands of dollars. It's the way that  these companies interact. If you're a startup,   and this is one of the reasons why we patent,  you want to have typically a portfolio of some   sort that defines the area you're doing that is  basically your intellectual property so that when
VCs and other people that you're working  with and you want to raise money from they   can see the patent as part of your value, your  patent portfolio. It helps you as a startup.

I think there are reasons for them. The rule  of law I think at the end of the day is very   good for the world, and if you didn't have it,  these companies would just bust up each other's   property, right? You resort to violence or means  that are in the physical world, and patents is in   this kind of capital world or intellectual world.  That's kind of how they play it out. I think   it's better having a rule of law than not. On the other hand if you apply it against a lone   person like you, it can be pretty intimidating.  It can be frustrating. I think for this to be a   really deep issue, you have to get typically to  a point where they notice you. Right? There are   companies all the time that are starting up in  areas that are crowded with patents. I work with   a lot of them here that come out of the Media  Lab. They're too small now to get hit with all   these patents that are floating around. They  get a bit bigger, companies or even individual   inventors to have these patents and work with  these law firms that are pro bono or not pro bono,   they're just guns for hire, will see  an opportunity to extract a toll.

They'll go after these companies with these  patents that kind of vaguely relate to   what they're doing, usually not. It involves  legal proceedings, so they want a settlement,   some sort of a tax, can be variable level. If  you're a troll, it can be a significant tax. If   you're just a little inventor and you just want  to be bought off by a relatively small amount,   so they use the patents that way. When  you get big enough to be a target, you're   going to start getting patents thrown at you. From people like this woman, from people that are   just inventors because there are people that just  come up with these ideas or they think they do,   they file some patent. Then in order to monetize  this process, they try to attach the companies   and lucrative enterprises to get some sort of  a tax. So you see that quite a bit as well. You   have to get typically to a certain size before  it gets to be a problem. By that time, hopefully,   you've got a strategy of dealing with this when  it happens because you're more of a company.

You're not just Jie and Bunnie trying to do it  on your own. Of course, in your case you had the   resources of MIT if you needed it because this  we're done here. MIT will defend its research   if somebody goes after you. This happened to  us. We haven't had people throw patents at me,   but people basically coming after us saying we  have this thing, we've done this work, blah,   blah, blah. If it gets to be a threat, the MIT  legal office can come in and actually help you.
Usually that diffuses it. It shuts it down  immediately once we get the legal office   involved if you're a lone inventor  and you don't have that. Thanks to

PatentPanda, maybe there's some recourse. I would like to add a little bit on the scale   of things before we do questions, which is that  it is actually a really good point. It really   depends on the size because if you think about it  or if I think about it in my opinion, not a fact,   people typically go after you. They'll throw  lawsuits, they'll send you these cease and desist   letters to basically try to make money. If you're  too little and broke to be able to pay real money,   there's really not that much incentive for them  to come after you. For better or for worse,   that's actually something that can make you or me  feel a little bit better where it's like, "Well,

I can keep making. Maybe this is right.  Maybe this is not. But even if it's not,   will someone come after me because I have nothing  to give? Unless you're harming someone's business   or they think they can make some sort of money  off of you, there's less of a chance of that.
I'm not saying that's always the case. Oh, P.S., I'm not a lawyer. This is not   legal advice. This is my opinion because you  can't practice law without a degree. Same with

PatentPandas, it's for educational purposes only.  I think scale and who you are kind of has a big   part of it, so even though in theory one might be  infringing and by law you shouldn't be doing this,   in practice things are often so different, and  that's why it's so important to have those Sherpa,   like actual lawyers, kind of tell you what's  the truth versus what's written down. I thought   that was kind of really important and one of the  biggest lessons that I learned. Thanks, Joe.

I think that's a great way to put it. You never  know, right? People can hassle each other about   anything if they're mad enough. Generally  to be a serious target of a patent lawsuit   there's got to be something worth suing. So  you get a company of a certain size, you're   going to attract them like bees to honey at that  point, but you have to cross a threshold. Then you   have some legal mechanism that can just deflect  them, deflect them quickly, like little gnats you   just swat them. There's a snake that's trying to  gobble you up, then you have to very carefully,   when a snake gobbles up panda, you have to  very carefully build your defense. That's   more expensive, more complicated. But then you're  big enough that hopefully you can deal with it.
There's another thing in defensive patents. I  mean, look, it's totally flawed. We can kick

80% of them out without much trouble. Right? It's  a flawed system in many ways. The patent office   realizes it. It's great that we have this new  thing with the prior art archive. The examiners   really as you said they only look usually at other  patents. Even working with the patent lawyers,   they prefer another patent than some paper 90% of  the time because the lawyers, the patent appeals   board, will understand another patent right  away. A paper you have to define, oh, yeah,   really we came out then and really was publicly  available. There's a bit more of a process to   defend it. Patents easier, it was obviously  there because it's in the system. This new   thing hopefully may make that more transparent. Trade Secrets are the antithesis to patents. This   is the thing, if you got rid of patents companies  still are going to have problems. They're going to   try to nudge each other out of the way. Granted  if they can't resort to mafia style terrorism,   physical terrorism, they work with trade secrets.  I've seen a bit of that. That's uglier because a   trade secret is more about what's in your head,  what's in your employee's head at a given time.

If you were working with company A and go to work  with company B afterward, company A gets upset   about company B and they sue for trade secret  violation. It involves individuals, not just   institutions. Patent is about knowledge. Trade  secret is about what an individual divulged.
It's about he said/she said and not so much  about this is prior art/this is not prior art.

It's a dirtier trial. Patents despite their  problems are cleaner. They're much cleaner   because they're above it. As an expert, I can say  this was known at that time because of this work   and this clearly anticipated this. Sometimes you  combine two or three things, one or two things,   always better to just have one thing, but as  a clear argument this was known in the art,   and this claim is useless because  of it. It's about the knowledge,   not about what somebody said or divulged. Patents serve purposes. They're flawed though.

They're not the best way to do it. Maybe we get  into the era when everybody is doing very well   with the ubiquitous robot economy, and we all  have social welfare to make a living and just   do cool things because they're cool. I think  it's the ideal future with music. Some of us   have talked about that. We have to make money out  of royalties. That's another kind of IP. You just   do the stuff you like and you're supported to do  it. I think the world is so much better off when   that happens. When we get there that would be  great. Until we get there, we're going to have   something like what we see with patents. Thanks, Joe. I guess with that maybe I would   like to invite my sister, May, up. We would  love to answer some questions. For folks who   might be tuning in remotely I have my phone  on PatentPandas, so you can go on Twitter at

PatentPandas and then send us a question if you  like, but in the meantime maybe if there's some   questions in the audience, we'd be happy. Is that recording? All right. First off,   thank you so much. This is an awesome resource.  I guess given what you just mentioned about the   idea of music and other types of IP, do you  plan to maybe expand this later on to like   a copyright or other things? I know that  you've only had this experience with your   personal experience here, but it seems like  a really great idea especially expanding   it beyond for other areas that students and  other researchers might run into around here.

Sorry, thank you. Yeah, that would be really cool.  I have to admit we will do one at a time and this   one is the most emotionally motivated one for  me right now, but I don't know, copyright cat   or something would probably make a lot. We thought  about it. It was like, "Trademark Turtle," I don't   know what starts with a T, but, yeah, maybe.  If we could find the help and the resources,
I think it'd be really cool to expand. There's also other stuff happening at the

Media Lab. There's the Berkeley School of Music  Media Lab thing that we've done, which is looking   really mainly at future copyright and protection  of work by individual artists so that you can get   some traceability and remuneration for your work  when it actually goes out. It's more defending   the work as opposed to taking down copyright  and thinking of new ways to do that. It's very,   very active. Lots of ideas are proposed  through that, and it's all open, so you can   look into it. I think it's called the open music  consortium or something like that. I mean, I'm not   a huge fan of copyrighting music either because  I'm a fan of Negativland as you some of you know   and what they had to go through for really making  new works of art out of other's people music   was horrible. I like musicians to be  paid at the end of the day somehow.

Other questions? Yes. Thank you, Jie. Seems super helpful,   and I know I've heard some of the stories from  you in the past, but it's really neat to see it   up kind of holistically presented on the website.  I have two questions, one of which was born out   of an experience that ESOF and I had with MedRec  when we were trying to get that patented through   the lab. The question was, we both wanted an open  patent. We didn't want to use it because neither   of us had the bandwidth nor do we now to try to  do a startup around it. We wanted to keep other   companies from absorbing it and then meaning that  we couldn't use it in the future. It seemed maybe   at the time that the Media Lab was less interested  in an open patent because it wasn't a clear case   to be made for the benefit of a member company. I guess my first question is, has that changed or   could open patents still be pursued at the Media  Lab in some beneficial way? The second question   for you guys is how is it on the international  scene, and do you have thoughts, Joe, in   particular about China and IP sharing or battles  between different countries that may or may not   respect each other's respective patent laws? I can say a tiny bit about open patents since   that's the thing that I was trying to research  when this project started, which is that the   patent itself isn't open or closed, it's what  permissions you give to it. I imagine what would   happen is you would get a patent through the Media  Lab and they would have to be okay open licensing   it. My understanding, although I could be wrong,  is that patents are really expensive, so a cheap   one is 10K. A normal one, 20K. A complex one like  the one you might have if you were here is closer   to $30,000. As a business model it doesn't quite  work. That would be my cynical view. I don't   know. Perhaps the policy is different. At least when I think about the technology   licensing for MIT as a whole, I've kind of talked  to them a little bit about open source, open et   cetera. They were like, "Yeah, if you don't want  to patent something, we're not going to make you,   but if you do, we want to make money from the  patent that we got." So that was the reaction   that I got from the higher level technology  licensing here at MIT. Maybe the Media Lab   is different. Maybe Joe can add to that. Yeah, I think Jie hit the nail on the head in   that for us to do a patent we have to invest  money behind it, significant money. Usually,   we'll want the argument in the IP com, the IP  committee that meets here why you want a patent   and typically to defend a startup or to work with  a sponsor or something of that sort. In this case,   actually there are lots of people interested in  MedRec, so I don't know exactly why. I think your   advisor wanted it to be open, and maybe didn't  like the idea of patenting for that reason.

I mean one other possibility is to file a really  bad patent. So people file provisionals all the   time, which are just the paper. You could sit  down and just write your paper and then make   up some claims, whatever, you don't care. The  prior art aren't the claims in the patent. No   one cares about if using patent for  prior art about the claims so much,   it's the disclosure. It's what you write  down before that. You could write down   whatever you want before that and then just  make up some claims. It would get rejected,   but it's going to be there as prior art, and  that disclosure is always there. That's-

I have something to add on that point, a  clarification which is that you can make   prior art by publishing research papers. You can  take that provisional patent if you got one and   just put it on your website and archive it on  Wayback Machine. If you just submit it to the

USPTO as a provisional patent, that's actually not  prior art because it's never published. The USPTO   doesn't actually read provisional patents, so they  wouldn't know about it. It only becomes prior art   if you publish it on the web where other people  can access it. It's a very strange quirk.

Provisionals are weird. They're only good  when you get a patent issued because it gives   you a priority date. If you actually file an  application, you can make a crappy application,   and that would work. The application would  be published, but it costs money to file an   application too. That's thousands of dollars.  It's not $10,000, maybe it's a few thousand.

And then you have to maintain it, but you  wouldn't maintain it, you'd abandon it,   so it's just the filing fee. I think this new  idea if there are ways of learning examiners. I   don't know why they just look at other patents.  I mean, there may be some legal argument.

They have little time. Yeah, time is the big deal. I've dealt with   examiners. Actually, one of them even called me at  home because he wanted to resolve a claim issue,   wanted to talk to my patent lawyer, and he  retired, couldn't get a hold of him. It was   amazing. This guy called at 9:00, he's blah, blah,  blah patent examiner. What? It was a fake call. He   talked about the patent. He knew about it, so it  really was him. These guys are under the gun.

What lawyers will do, we talked about that,  they'll wear them down. If you're working   with a firm and they want to get their patents  accepted so the law firm is going to try to get   them accepted. Even here at the Media Lab we do  that. You quite often won't get rejections on   the claims. Sometimes it's because the examiner  doesn't get them. Sometimes he has good prior   art. There's always a dance. If a company really  wants that patent, they're going to wear the   examiner down, the lawyers will wear the examiner  down. They'll keep doing new appeals to office   actions, and they'll change a few words here  and there. Eventually, I've seen cases where   the examiner just gives up, and the patent is  issued even though it's clearly the examiner's   right to reject. He's rejected it four times,  five times. He's coming up with different patents,   different reasons. They change a few words,  and he's just, "Oh, I'll let you have it."

He's under pressure probably and the patent  gets out whenever they shouldn't. There's the   job of the people like me to doing IPRs where  we kick them out, but that's a lot of careful   work whereas the examiner if he was able  to do his job properly would've kicked it   out and he was trying to kick it out. Better  tools for examiners to reject patents that   are bogus would be wonderful and bringing in  other prior art is a good way to do it. We're   living in an era of ubiquitous knowledge. If  we could bring more of that bear, I think we'd   have stronger patents that are real patents and  ones that are just redundant ideally wouldn't   make it all the way across to make trouble. For international stuff, that's a great issue,   very current issue. I'm not an expert in that.  I mean, if a patent is important to a sponsor   company here at the Media Lab, we'll enable  a PCT to be filed, which lets us file patents   around the world. We get a year or so to file  them in the EU and China wherever we want to do   it. It costs money for that. So we don't fund it  ourselves. We have to get that money coming from   the company that wants to license the patent. I'll elaborate a tiny bit to just explain what   that means. So if you're not super familiar with  patents you may not realize that patents only have   say in the country that they're filed in, so you  can get a patent in the US, you can get a patent   in China, and many other countries. But if you  have a patent in the US and you don't have one   in a different country, you don't have rights  to that invention in the other country. A PCT   is something that you can file when you first file  your original patent that says you hold this spot,   you reserve the right to be able to apply for  those same patents in all these other countries.

You can imagine it gets pretty expensive to try to  get a patent in each of the different countries,   which is probably why people typically don't. It's kind of a tricky situation. I   just wanted to give that background. Patents in other countries can be used as   prior art too. So a German patent I've been  on cases where German patents are used to   halt other patents or patents from various  places. The other thing that can happen is   a defense. I don't know if we can go over  products in China. There's probably ways,   more diplomatic pressure working with  companies that work in the US and China   together. We can haul products at the border  here, and I've been involved in cases with   the Federal Trade Commission where there's  a violation and you can go after people that   way. It's like going through patent court, a  district court or an IPR, so on and so forth.

You can actually go to the Federal Trade  Commission and say there's a violation   and we want to stop the patents at the border. Even though it's made in China, blah, blah, blah,   blah, this is a violation of our intellectual  property rights here, so I'm going to stop these   products before they enter the US. There could  be something inside of an iPhone, for example,   right? It's an American manufacturer, it's made  in China, but there's some issue about the IP   with this thing and some part of it's chain. So  you can stop that thing at the border before it   comes in. It could be a trade secret too. Maybe I'll add two more comments. I'm also not   an expert on international patent law, but I do  understand that ... What was I going to say? In

China there's also a patent system, and so people  can apply for patents. My understanding is that   it's very hard for someone who's not a Chinese  citizen to get a patent, so you have to like   find a sponsor there, so it's super complicated.  It is very hard. I think that's probably some of   the issue. I don't know. I am not an expert. A kind of interesting antidote though is   that people seem to really believe  strongly in the US patent system,   and so one reason why many people in other  countries might get it is because it's like,
"Hey, if your invention is valid enough to get a  patent in the US, there must be some legs to what   you're doing." So that's kind of one part where  it might come up, but, again, not an expert.
